intro: Quercus ilex var. spinosa, commonly known as the Kermes Oak, is a variant of the evergreen oak native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves that are typically 2–5 cm long and have a distinctive spine-like tip. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in the spring, followed by small, inedible acorns. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or coastal areas. This variety is known for its hardy nature and ability to withstand drought and salt spray.
